content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
From an objective standpoint (Pros)WWE 2K16 does its darndest to provide whatever it can for the fans to enjoy out of the game, but its gameplay and pace restrict it to a certain demographic.When it comes to gameplay and controls, the pace may feel a little slow for an audience that comes from a twitch-timing lineup of games. Regardless, it matches very well to the way we normally see pro wrestling matches and doesn't falter from the unrealistic side of things by far except for physics which barely matters and how much of an impact it would have to set the outcome of a match. Mini games at the start and end of a match fairly tell in comparison on what superstars can do against each other, and it works well. Realistically, the game does its darndest to keep the competition from going one-sided way too quickly without limiting a player's capabilities.Online multiplayer is a subjective matter, and performance may vary depending on which player faces which along with their Internet connection.As far as features go, you can go pretty far with creating things of your own. There are limits, though, as there's only so much you can build out of your superstar, logo, show and arena when you wish to share them with the online community. If you want, you can also make an alternate attire out of other WWE superstars. I can finally dress up John Cena in his generic green trunks since his first debut in the WWE.In addition, you get to relive some of WWE's history back in the early years of the World Wrestling Federation with "Macho Man" Randy Savage and Jake "The Snake" Roberts. Various conditions and seeing the outcome of each match as is recorded in history is eye-catching. But the commentary from today's announcers disconnects the legendary vibe some. You never hear Mr. McMahon's angsty dialogue at ringside apart from replays and historic vignettes. Plus, performing these feats as accurately as possible is a way to unlock content. Austin 3:16, which is the staple of the game, demonstrates the evolution of Steve Austin and the franchise as a whole as he turns the tides to his favor with his new face and attitude since his first appearance and pains in his career. This shows that not everything in the franchise is all sunshine and bunnies, and is an appropriate chapter to show in the midst of the franchise's history.The roster is definitely plentiful, but selective as usual, with the lineup consisting majorly from NXT and this era's superstars from SmackDown! and RAW. DLC also has a fairly impressive amount of selections, from legends to new bloods to Arnold "The Terminator" Schwarzenegger.Compared to previous games (cons)The pace of the game is much slower compared to previous games, but relates a lot more to pro wrestling in real life. There are limits to what a superstar can do before they are worn out, and to keep things an a more level playing field, reversal opportunities are limited. You are fated to take the pain if you exert too much from the start. It's up to you if you want to set momentum, but how you adapt to the superstar you are playing as is more important than ever. At least nobody feels like a cardboard cut-out in that regard. A five-star rating will not be as easy as before.As I said before, there is a limit with how much you can make with your superstars, shows, and arenas. It saves bandwidth and server space when sharing content with other players. You'd have to improvise with what you can to make the most accurate appearance of what you're going for as possible with little resources. While it's convenient to access other players' creations in-game, the limit with what you can create in order to share and play online with them is disappointing. If I had a suggestion, it'd be to remove the limits and advise me that I can't share them until I lighten the loads. That way, it's more universal and less stressful for both the creators and the WWE Creations server.One presentation name I used in previous WWE games was "The Vampire". But it wasn't available from a few games back and I had to settle with "The Monster" instead. Presentation names are plentiful and there's quite a variety. But the pot gets stirred more often than not between each WWE game released. If you've been maining with the same created superstar and presentation name, you might be disappointed.I'm quite happy with the roster selection this game, and even happier that we are able to design alternate attires for our WWE superstars, something that had been missing for many generations. But don't expect all alumni to make an appearance in this game. Sorry, Hulkamaniacs.The only reason I would recommend this game is because it's been many, MANY years since a WWE game has been released on PC. But that isn't saying much. If you're new to the franchise and want to get your feet wet, this would be the best place to start before getting acquainted with previous pro wrestling games on consoles from two decades ago (some of which are better). But if you just care about gameplay and creativity, skip this one out-right.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												In not that much of a fan of the WWE, but I like wrestling games. I do recommend this game, since it's pretty good and perhaps is the best one available for PC. However, there are a few things that I don't like, I hate or I simply wished they haven't removed.Cons-No custom matches: Which means you may only play with the ones defined by the game. Not a big variety and you can no longer change things like "win by Finisher only" and stuff like that.-No symetry when creating superstars or divas. You edit things with points and the lack of a symetry tool makes the process a bit tedius.-I know it's the PG era and stuff, but I do miss the intergender matches. You can kinda "hack" wrestlers to be able to fight intergender, but it could increase the risk of crashing the game.-Wrestler creation process is in general slow and lacks of previews... but keep reading. XDPros-In depth wrestler creation. If you take your time working on this, you can get pretty awesome results. There are certain limits but in general creationg is pretty cool. Even when you can't preview anything and the process is slow, if you enjoy spending hours customizing, this game is good.-Sharing content. Or if you're lazy and are looking for Deadpool, Rainbow Dash or Undertaker in another outfit... you can just see if someone already made it and download it.-Universe mode. Kind of like a story mode, which can be customized. For example, you can select only your custom supersatrs to be part of the matches, set the championships and stuff. Way better than the actual story mode.-Good gameplay. As any wrestling game lately, it takes a bit of time to get used to it, but it's pretty well done.Long story short: If only intergender matches were a thing, as well as match creation/customization... I'd love this game. As it is now, I just think it's good.

												This game is a huge step up from wwe 2k15, the action feels fluid and the gameplay feels more like the near unbeatable fire pro wrestling series than an arcadey brawler like the old games, thatâ€™s not say that this game is complicated as the controls are streamlined and work the. AI actually gives you a fun and entertaining match ala fire pro(not on that level but getting there) the graphics are very pleasing to the eye, in most cases the wrestlers look like there real life counterparts, the creation suite is almost back to it's former glory, your caws this year look unique and donâ€™t just look like the same random jobber with a costume change, create an arena is back in this years installment and not a lot has changed, you can create a cool area however it does at time feel limited, career mode is back as well and is still a slog but is also somewhat enjoyable in small doses, universe mode remains pretty much unchanged which is sad as it is one mode that gives the game replayability all in all Iâ€™d give wwe 2k16 a 7 out of ten an enjoyable yet flawed experience that should tide you over till the next installment

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												2K16 is a pretty solid game that is a good gateway to understanding the appeal of professional wrestling. Not only does it cover the highlights of the poster child of WWE's Attitude Era "Stone Cold" Steve Austin, but high points of the newest Hall of Famers like Alundra Blayze, Rikishi, and "Macho Man" Randy Savage. Needless to say, experiencing Career Mode is a good place to start for anyone that wants to know why people tune in to buff guys pretending to hate each other (sometimes) and not-so-pretending to beat the Hell out of each other.For those who want just a match, the roster is enormous and the modes are varied.Wrestling is an inherently creative endeavor, and with 2K16's tools, creativity is encouraged. Build custom wrestlers with their entrances, arenas, shows, tag teams, championship belts.Universe Mode is like being in charge of your WWE programming lineup, which means you can make something better than current programming easily.While no means an absoultely complete and flawless experience, it's pretty close.9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												The incredible presentation and amazing roster of characters are somewhat tarnished by the new game mechanics used for pinning and submissions.  Computer opponents will kick out of most pins no matter how battered and bruised they are unless you hit them with a finisher.  This can make matches a grind to build up your momentum bar often more than twice in order to win.  The new submission system is clumsily implemented and caused controller breaking frustration at first.  At least 50% of gamers seem to be having problems with this new system for submissions.  I researched online and found some helpful advice from gamers who understood how to use it successfuly, so persevere if you're having trouble with it!  Overall however the pros far outweigh the cons in my opinion.  The insanely huge roster spans decades of professional wrestling and includes a lot of exciting big names.  Improvements to the 'My Career' mode make it even more exciting and involving than before, in many ways this is the best wrestling sim ever made.  It's a huge improvement over WWE 2K15 and if you forgive the two new clumsy game mechanics you'll enjoy some of the rawest, most realistic and well paced wrestling action ever devised for a computer game.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Contrary to what some are saying about performance, I can confirm that you can absolutely melt your GPU off with insane frame count if you're running a higher end system.The game runs fabulous for me but I keep V Sync on to stop 3452 fps coil whine from getting out of control.Pros to this years offering?Improved CAW, though masks and facepaint still leave a lot to be desired.Slightly better visuals than last year on PC.It's a Triple A wrestling game on PC!!!Game mechanics are improved over the b.s. that was 2k15 (even though I liked that title too)Cons?the CAW voice can not be changed and the voiceovers and dialogue leave a LOT to be desired.Rivalries, while pretty cool, are super repetitive especially in the early stages of your career.It takes literally for ever to get to main event status (at least in my experience thus far).Overall the game is really well designed in my opinion, and being able to download smarkyâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥from the 2k creations hub thing is great for any fan of the actual business itself. You can also download and run some pretty well put together CAW's from the hub who look like new WWE additions, or some other indie faves or past wrestlers who did not make it in.If you've got the cash now go for it. I picked up 2k15 last year for $13.99 but had no trouble getting this years offering on release day for PC at full price.

												Much improved to last year's 2k15.  Pretty much most of last year's complaints were addressed and fixed.  Larger roster, faster load times, double the CAW slots and most important, better optimization.  Last year's ran like a slug and crashed often in all but high end PCs.  2k16 runs much better.  I can actually run the Royal Rumble now with my middle spec PC.  There is still occasional slow down and random crashes, But so much less frequent  than 2k15.   With the community mods adding in custom Wrestlers, arenas, music & menus, this will be the definitive Wrestling game on the PC.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Bought the game and subsequently returned it.Pros -  - Customization is great. I spent a lot of time making a cool superstar with an awesome intro. I liked him. He was gonna go far. - Graphics are all pretty good. Nothing amazing, but largely appropriate for the time. - Music selections didn't make me want to jam a screwdriver in my ear. Well, not the first few times through the rotation, anyway.Cons -  - Music gets repetitive real quick.  - Controls are incomprehensible. There are so many layers of abstraction between me and the moves I want to do that it ends up being a series of mind-numbing mini-games rather than something that even resembles a fight. "Rotate the controller until the blue dot turns red and fills up the gauge." "Rotate the controller until the red triangle is under the blue triangle." "Press A when the bar fills up to the tapout button."  etc., etc., etc. Not to mention, of course, the ridiculousness of attempting to counter a move, wherein you may only succeed in doing so if you press R2 at the exact right moment, not before, not after, but if you wait until you receive the prompt on-screen, it's already too late. - Tutorials teach you very little, while simultaneously penalizing your long-term progress for not yet knowing the rules or controls.  It honestly took me 5 minutes to figure out how to leave the ring after tagging in my partner because the game never explained it, but sure as hell was happy to have me lose the match to disqualification. - Kayefabe.    Call me a romantic, but I'm not at all interested in seeing how the sausage gets made. I don't ever want to see my supernaturally themed, giant death-man of badassery smiling and high-fiving people while back-stage at the NXT performance center, or looking at Triple H with a wide-eyed stare and a "put me in, Coach!" attitude. None of my fantasies about wrestling, none of the things I've ever enjoyed about it, have come from the idea of getting in the ring and seeing it all from the other side. What I want to see is that Randy Orton lives in a straight jacket, that John Cena salutes himself in the mirror every morning, that Bray Wyatt holds strange rituals down on his farm and that The New Day wake up every morning and eat a big 'ol bowl of Booty-o's. I want the fantasy. I want the stories and the characters. The Undertaker isn't very cool if he's just some guy named Mark.  - Loadscreens upon loadscreens, upon loadscreens! For a 20 gig game, you'd think they could have smoothed this out a bit, but instead every other menu requires a minute-long load screen just to change an option or select the next match. WHY?!  (well, I know why, but I didn't want this to just be a rant about crummy console porting) - - Overall - - Nah.  Unless you're a SUPER-HARDCORE-ULTRA-UBER-MEGA-FAN of the series already, this isn't really worth the time it takes to make it worthwhile. Just go watch the 900+ hours of content on the WWE Network ("For only 9.99!") and give this mess a pass.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Most wrestling fans agree that showmanship is at least as important as technical, in-ring ability, and WWE 2K16 doesnâ€™t quite nail all its big spots in this regard. Technically, itâ€™s kind of all over the place: there are no load times between ring entrances, lending a seamless, TV-broadcast feel to match openings, but the loads between other modes, and even just to preview a costume piece in create-a-wrestler can be painful. Sometimes the AI behaves uncannily like the wrestler you know and love, like when Seth Rollins tries to DQ himself to retain the belt, and other times, they quizzically zone out and sort of stare off into space. This same inconsistency spills over into other areas. Visually, some character models and effects look terrific, like during Randy Ortonâ€™s ring entrance, while guys like Chris Jerico seem to be holdovers from the last-gen days.  WWE 2K16 doesnâ€™t quite nail all its big spotsFinally, the commentary has improved greatly, with far fewer repeated phrases, and more specific insight into many wrestlersâ€™ fighting style and history, but itâ€™s not all the way there yet. There are still a few too many general move callouts, making the play-by-play a bit flat at times. No one issue is big enough to ruin the fun, but together they can periodically undercut the tension and excitement the in-ring action builds sort of stare off into space. via http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/10/30/wwe-2k16-reviewI'm going to be honest here and anyone who does not know anything about wwe12 (GTFO)Where is the unstopable dead man? This newer version of undertaker is not an overwhelming force and what happen to his promos for ppv...let alone his skill to vanish before catching you from behind.The wwe universe has more to offer now but a lot has been left undone; this game is far from finished....Where is the backstage brawls? The NXT and superstars arena do not sync right and are left unfinished....Lack of animation and there is a lot of outside ring moves missing...Oh lets not forget the weight detection....Your okay with someone not playing fair? I would rater play the computer on legend, then someone who can somehow always beat you(even if you have the same amount of reversals)....

												Even though I was unable to play it on my current computer (a laptop), I still enjoyed it on a console, that being my Xbox 360 for Christmas. And seeing there are more features and things for this and the Xbone/PS4 versions, what I got is pretty entertaining, even though I do have to spend the money for the Season Pass DLC, which in the PC version is all conveniently add in for free.And I'll admit it does have its flaws, the ability to create your wrestler is as enjoyable as it always been, and I'm happy about creating my own arena, logo (albiet frustrating), and belts, which I was happy to see back since Smackdown Vs RAW 2008. And seeing having 100 slots for created wrestlers really adds to the ability to create characters off of cartoons and video games, and even original wrestlers.I haven't went through the 2K3:16 Showcase (and the Xbone/PS4/PC version's MyCareer mode) yet, but I still find it enjoyable. I recommend getting this game, as least on consoles, but if your PC is powerful enough (unlike mine at the time of publishing this review), then its also worth checking out, even if getting it at $50 is a bit much for your liking. :3

content:
Posted: February 21
												I wish I could give this game a "neutral" review.There's a lot to like here, but the biggest is simple: it's at least a relatively good wrestling game with an appreciable number of WWE wrestlers in it, and this is basically the only place you're going to find it. If that's what you want, this game has it, and you will probably find a way to be happy with it, if you want it badly enough.The game has got flaws, however. It's a console port, and I don't mean that in a good way. Some console ports are well done, but this one seems very cut-and-pasted into Windows. If you were expecting ANY part of this to take advantage of being on Windows, forget it. Their posted system requirements are laughable, unless you're playing with all the settings turned off in 720p at 60Hz refresh (and you probably aren't). A 750 Ti didn't get me to 60 fps at 1080p; only an upgrade to a 1060 could do that.You still can't use your own music for your created wrestler. You still can't use your own video for your created wrestler. Understandable (barely) on a console, but how was this overlooked on PC (see "not a great port," above).However, as stated, if you want a good wrestling game with WWE wrestlers, and you want it on PC? This will get you there. But you'll wonder why more couldn't have been done.

												It's pretty fun. Universe Mode in particular is a ton of fun with a bit of imagination (since using the Rivalries function will just basically give you the rivals fighting each other every week, and then again at the PPV). Booking things on your own will get you a ton more enjoyment out of it. Showcase is fun as well, depending on if you're into reliving the past or seeing/hearing about the past for the first time. MyCareer is kinda lame in my opinion. It reminds me of the Career Mode from like, SvR2009. Which was basically just a series of matches. Overall though, it's the most fun I've had with a wrestling game since No Mercy on the N64, so I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Most wrestling fans agree that showmanship is at least as important as technical, in-ring ability, and WWE 2K16 doesnâ€™t quite nail all its big spots in this regard. Technically, itâ€™s kind of all over the place: there are no load times between ring entrances, lending a seamless, TV-broadcast feel to match openings, but the loads between other modes, and even just to preview a costume piece in create-a-wrestler can be painful. Sometimes the AI behaves uncannily like the wrestler you know and love, like when Seth Rollins tries to DQ himself to retain the belt, and other times, they quizzically zone out and sort of stare off into space. This same inconsistency spills over into other areas. Visually, some character models and effects look terrific, like during Randy Ortonâ€™s ring entrance, while guys like Chris Jerico seem to be holdovers from the last-gen days.  WWE 2K16 doesnâ€™t quite nail all its big spotsFinally, the commentary has improved greatly, with far fewer repeated phrases, and more specific insight into many wrestlersâ€™ fighting style and history, but itâ€™s not all the way there yet. There are still a few too many general move callouts, making the play-by-play a bit flat at times. No one issue is big enough to ruin the fun, but together they can periodically undercut the tension and excitement the in-ring action builds sort of stare off into space. via http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/10/30/wwe-2k16-reviewI'm going to be honest here and anyone who does not know anything about wwe12 (GTFO)Where is the unstopable dead man? This newer version of undertaker is not an overwhelming force and what happen to his promos for ppv...let alone his skill to vanish before catching you from behind.The wwe universe has more to offer now but a lot has been left undone; this game is far from finished....Where is the backstage brawls? The NXT and superstars arena do not sync right and are left unfinished....Lack of animation and there is a lot of outside ring moves missing...Oh lets not forget the weight detection....Your okay with someone not playing fair? I would rater play the computer on legend, then someone who can somehow always beat you(even if you have the same amount of reversals)....

content:
Posted: January 3
Product received for free
												Even though I was unable to play it on my current computer (a laptop), I still enjoyed it on a console, that being my Xbox 360 for Christmas. And seeing there are more features and things for this and the Xbone/PS4 versions, what I got is pretty entertaining, even though I do have to spend the money for the Season Pass DLC, which in the PC version is all conveniently add in for free.And I'll admit it does have its flaws, the ability to create your wrestler is as enjoyable as it always been, and I'm happy about creating my own arena, logo (albiet frustrating), and belts, which I was happy to see back since Smackdown Vs RAW 2008. And seeing having 100 slots for created wrestlers really adds to the ability to create characters off of cartoons and video games, and even original wrestlers.I haven't went through the 2K3:16 Showcase (and the Xbone/PS4/PC version's MyCareer mode) yet, but I still find it enjoyable. I recommend getting this game, as least on consoles, but if your PC is powerful enough (unlike mine at the time of publishing this review), then its also worth checking out, even if getting it at $50 is a bit much for your liking. :3

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												Cons Career Mode> Not being able to go for multiple titles > When being interviewed your choices on what you can say do not show how they change your Personality traits> Targeting. Example in triple threat matches it is hard to target someone then try to attack the other person> More creations slots. So I can get more Shane O Mac attires > Starting a match the option to turn on and off entrances gone. This only happens when getting ran in on> Can only have 1 tag partner > No NXT tag team championship > Boring storylines that repeat over and over> No special Wrestlemania entrances>Authority orders make no sense example "Win by DQ" For a triple threat match> Star gage gets stuck> You wrestle every Raw and Smackdown. Also if you're in NXT you'll wrestle on Superstars and NXT+ pay per view> Getting a high relationship with another superstar will want them to tag team with you however if you do not want to be in a tag the relationship with go back to the bottom> Beating someone with a high relationship will cause them to dislike you more> You will cry and get angry because of this trashCons (of online)> Controls are delayed despite perfect connection> Many game modes missing like the Royal Rumble, Handicap matches and tournaments> There are no entrances (So don't spend 1 hour making an entrance to show off to your mates that they will never see)> Will get boring because you have to repeat gamemodes > You have to leave the lobby to change gamemodeOverall Universe Mode is a better career mode than career mode
